title: Links
desc: Links are easy to code accessibly, but it's nice to give more context.

title: Accessible Text in SVG
desc: How to ensure text in SVG respects WCAG 1.4.4 (Resize text) and WCAG 1.4.12 (Text Spacing).

title: ARIA Alert
desc: Learn about the ARIA alert property, how it enhances web accessibility, and explore practical examples with code samples. Master ARIA alerts for better UX.

title: Animated GIFs with Pause Buttons
desc: How to code Animated GIFs can be paused using the HTML5 details tag.

title: Accessible Buttons
desc: Native HTML5 buttons are the best when you have existing inaccessible code, using roles can help.

title: Carousels
desc: If you absolutely need carousels, you should really make them accessible and easily bypassed for keyboard and screen reader users.

title: Checkboxes
desc: Here is a step-by-step guide to creating accessible checkboxes

title: Code Patterns
desc: A list of all the accessible code patterns which can be found in the Enable project.

title: Accessible Autocomplete (a.k.a Combobox)
desc: One exception to the First Rule of ARIA is HTML5 autocomplete using the datalist tag, which is not as accessible as the ARIA datalist role.

title: Content
desc: Page that organizes the components that fall under Content.

title: Controls
desc: Page that organizes the components that fall under Controls.

title: Dark Mode
desc: This page will show you how to ensure your website has proper contrast as well as the overall function for dark mode.

title: Description List (ne√© Definition List)
desc: Lists of name/value pairs should be coded in a definition list.  This page covers the HTML5 and ARIA variants.

title: Modal Dialog
desc: Modal dialogs are often not made accessible.  This page covers, step by step, how to ensure your are.

title: Dropdowns/Drawers/Expandos
desc: No matter what you can them, dropdowns, drawers and expandos can be easily made accessible with just a little bit of markup.

title: Figures
desc: Often overlooked, self-contained content that is references in a document, like a photo, chart, diagram or code, should be marked up as a figure to help screen reader users understand context.

title: Focus Styling Tips
desc: Explore best practices for focus outlines in web design. Improve accessibility and keyboard navigation with our comprehensive guide.

title: Form Validation and Errors
desc: Learn how to make your form validation and error checking accessible. Follow best practices to ensure your web forms are compliant with WCAG guidelines and user-friendly for everyone.

title: Form Structure
desc: Learn about proper HTML form structure. You'd be surprised how often this is not done correctly.

title: Forms
desc: Page that organizes the components that fall under Forms.

title: Headings
desc: How headings are used by screen reader users, and how to code them in an existing document without a lot of rework.

title: Advanced Text Resizing
desc: How to make text in things like hero images be coded via HTML (WCAG 1.4.5) while still allowing text resizing (WCAG 1.4.4).

title: Images
desc: How to code both >img< tags and background images so they are understandable by screen reader users.

title: Infographics
desc: How to code SVG and bitmap images so they are understandable by screen reader users.

title: Input Masking
desc: How to code masking of keyboard input in form fields so they are accessible.

title: Select Boxes (a.k.a. Listboxes)
desc: Why it's preferable to use native HTML5 select controls vs custom controls, and what developers must do if they have to use a custom one.

title: ARIA Log
desc: Discover how to implement an Accessible Log Display with a live example and detailed code walkthrough. Enhance web accessibility with best practices.

title: ARIA Marquee
desc: Learn how to create an auto-scrolling Marquee for your web pages. Explore a live example and get detailed code samples to implement it effortlessly.

title: Meter
desc: Meter component which is supported by non html5 browsers.

title: Multimedia Content
desc: Is AI auto-captioning from services like Google, Facebook and Microsoft sufficient? Do you know what a transcript really is (hint: YouTube doesn't)? How can we make sure our videos don't cause seizures?  Learn how to make video content accessible.

title: Flyout/Hamburger Hybrid Menus
desc: A hard thing to code from scratch, many developers will use an existing library to create hybrid flyout/hamburger menus.  Most of them aren't accessible. Let's show you how they can be.

title: Pause Animation Controls
desc: Instructions on how you can create a global control on you site that pauses animations while respecting your operating animation system settings.

title: Accessible Progress Bars
desc: HTML5 Progress Bars should be coded so users who use screen readers and assistive technology know they are there what they are trying to tell them.

title: Radio Groups
desc: Here is a step-by-step guide to creating accessible radio groups

title: Skip Links (That Work In Mobile Too!)
desc: Traditional skip links (e.g. Skip Navigation Links) that are visible only on focus don't work on mobile. This page presents an example of one that does.

title: Sliders (a.k.a Range Input)
desc: This page is a perfect example of why the First Rule of ARIA (i.e. don't use ARIA) is so relevant, especially for mobile screen reader users.

title: Numeric Fields
desc: Many developers think form fields with numeric values must always be coded as >input type="number"<.  There are exceptions.

title: ARIA Status
desc: Learn about the ARIA status role, its importance in accessibility, and see a live example with supporting code samples to improve user experience.

title: ARIA Switch (a.k.a. Toggle)
desc: A control with no native HTML5 equivalent, switches have become popular recently in web and mobile applications, but many are inaccessible to screen reader and keyboard-only users.  Here's how to code them correctly.

title: Simple Accessible Tables
desc: Learn the small things you didn't know were needed for HTML5 tables. Also learn how to make sortable and paginated tables accessible to everyone.

title: Accessible Sortable Tables
desc: With a little bit of JavaScript, you can make your tables sortable, but you should make sure you mark them up correctly.

title: Accessible Pagination Table
desc: If you have a large amount of data, many developers will code pagination widgets to show small portions of data in the table at a time.  Learn how to make that UI accessible, or just use our NPM module to do this.

title: Content That Scrolls In Two Dimensions (a WCAG Reflow Violation)
desc: In all breakpoints, you should ensure users don't have to scroll horizontally and vertically to understand the content (with some exceptions).  This page talks about common solutions you can use to fix these type of issues.

title: Search Form
desc: If you have a search form on your page, make sure it is coded correctly so it can not only be read by screen reader users, but also have the right landmark applied to it.

title: Tabs
desc: Another control with no native HTML5 tag, many developers don't realize their tab components aren't accessible. We've got your back.

title: Textboxes
desc: If you are using custom (i.e. non-native HTML5) textboxes, it's simple to add a few ARIA attributes to make them accessible, if you absolutely have to.

title: Resizable Typography
desc: How you can ensure that your website's typography resizes/zooms for people that use their browser's text zooming feature.

title: Space-Adjusting Typography
desc: How you can ensure that your website's typography is legible for users that adjust text-spacing because of dyslexia or due to visual or cognitive disabilities.

title: ARIA Timer
desc: Discover what ARIA Timer is, see a live example, and explore the supporting code. Learn how to implement an accessible countdown timer with ARIA roles and attributes.

title: Tooltip
desc: If you have a tooltip, ensure it follows accessibility best practices.

title: Video Player
desc: Videos on the web must have audio descriptions as well as captions to be WCAG AA compliant. Learn how to do so without a lot of cost and time and get a WCAG AAA transcript for free!

title: Accessible Code Quality
desc: What are the automated tools we use in Enable to ensure code quality.

title: Exposing Style Information To Screen Readers
desc: If you think the style of text on the page is important to screen reader users, how do you code it?

title: Screen Reader Only Text
desc: What is screen reader only text, when it should be used and how it differs from aria-labels.

title: Bookmarklets to Test Accessibility Features On A Page
desc: The bookmarklets on this page are designed to help developers check if certain features are coded correctly on a webpage.
